pageProps.contentHtml:
Lp spaces, operator theory
  1. Prove that Lp([0,1],μ)L^p\p{\br{0,1}, \mu}Lp([0,1],μ) are separable Banach spaces for 1≤p<∞1 \leq p < \infty1≤p<∞ but L∞([0,1],μ)L^\infty\p{\br{0,1}, \mu}L∞([0,1],μ) is not.
  2. Prove that there exists no linear bounded surjective map T ⁣:Lp([0,1],μ)→L1([0,1],μ)\func{T}{L^p\p{\br{0,1}, \mu}}{L^1\p{\br{0,1}, \mu}}T:Lp([0,1],μ)→L1([0,1],μ) if p>1p > 1p>1.
Solution.

  1. Since step functions are dense in Lp([0,1])L^p\p{\br{0,1}}Lp([0,1]) for 1≤p<∞1 \leq p < \infty1≤p<∞, it suffices to show that step functions can be approximated by a countable set. Consider

    V={∑j=1ncjχ[aj,bj] | n∈N, aj,bj∈Q∩[0,1], cj∈Q}.V = \set{\sum_{j=1}^n c_j \chi_{\br{a_j, b_j}} \st n \in \N,\ a_j, b_j \in \Q \cap \br{0,1},\ c_j \in \Q}.V={j=1∑n​cj​χ[aj​,bj​]​∣∣​n∈N, aj​,bj​∈Q∩[0,1], cj​∈Q}.

    By linearity, it suffices to show that we can approximate functions of the form cχ[a,b]c\chi_{\br{a, b}}cχ[a,b]​, but this is easy by density of Q\QQ in R\RR and the dominated convergence theorem, so VVV is dense in Lp([0,1])L^p\p{\br{0,1}}Lp([0,1]), so it is separable.

    When p=∞p = \inftyp=∞, consider en=χ(1n+1,1n)e_n = \chi_{\p{\frac{1}{n+1}, \frac{1}{n}}}en​=χ(n+11​,n1​)​ so that each ene_nen​ have disjoint supports. Let

    A={∑j=1∞σjej | σj∈{0,1}},A = \set{\sum_{j=1}^\infty \sigma_j e_j \st \sigma_j \in \set{0, 1}},A={j=1∑∞​σj​ej​∣∣​σj​∈{0,1}},

    which is in bijection with {0,1}N\set{0, 1}^\N{0,1}N, i.e., AAA is uncountable. Notice that if {σn}n≠{τn}n\set{\sigma_n}_n \neq \set{\tau_n}_n{σn​}n​={τn​}n​ are distinct elements of AAA, then there exists nnn such that σn≠τn\sigma_n \neq \tau_nσn​=τn​, and so ∑nσnen\sum_n \sigma_n e_n∑n​σn​en​ and ∑nτnen\sum_n \tau_n e_n∑n​τn​en​ differ on (1n+1,1n)\p{\frac{1}{n+1}, \frac{1}{n}}(n+11​,n1​), so distinct elements have distance at least 111. Thus, because AAA is uncountable, we see that L∞([0,1])L^\infty\p{\br{0,1}}L∞([0,1]) is not separable.

  2. Suppose otherwise, and that there exists such a TTT. We have the transpose T† ⁣:(L1([0,1]))∗→(Lp([0,1]))∗\func{T^\dagger}{\p{L^1\p{\br{0,1}}}^*}{\p{L^p\p{\br{0,1}}}^*}T†:(L1([0,1]))∗→(Lp([0,1]))∗, which is given by T†(λ)=λ∘TT^\dagger\p{\lambda} = \lambda \circ TT†(λ)=λ∘T. Notice that T†T^\daggerT† is injective: indeed, suppose T†(λ)=0T^\dagger\p{\lambda} = 0T†(λ)=0, and let g∈L1([0,1])g \in L^1\p{\br{0,1}}g∈L1([0,1]). Since TTT is surjective, there exists h∈Lp([0,1])h \in L^p\p{\br{0,1}}h∈Lp([0,1]) such that Th=gTh = gTh=g, so

    0=(T†λ)(h)=λ(Th)=λ(g).0 = \p{T^\dagger \lambda}\p{h} = \lambda\p{Th} = \lambda\p{g}.0=(T†λ)(h)=λ(Th)=λ(g).

    Thus, λ=0\lambda = 0λ=0, so T†T^\daggerT† has trivial kernel. But by Riesz representation, we see that

    L∞([0,1])⊆Lp/(p−1)([0,1]).L^\infty\p{\br{0,1}} \subseteq L^{p/\p{p-1}}\p{\br{0,1}}.L∞([0,1])⊆Lp/(p−1)([0,1]).

    But this contradicts the fact that L∞([0,1])L^\infty\p{\br{0,1}}L∞([0,1]) is not separable.
